measured_by: reduced MEP amplitude relative to single-pulse test stimulus
justification: “When the conditioning stimulus is delivered over a cortical region contralateral to the M1 test stimulus and results in a reduced MEP amplitude relative to single-pulse M1 TMS, the effects are referred to as interhemispheric inhibition (IHI) [19].”

measured_by: increased MEP amplitude relative to single-pulse test stimulus
justification: “Conversely, an increase in MEP amplitude resulting from similar bilateral positioning of TMS coils is referred to as interhemispheric facilitation (IHF) [20].”

measured_by: Motor Evoked Potentials (MEP) elicited by single-pulse TMS over M1 and recorded with EMG
justification: “When applied over the primary motor cortex (M1), TMS can elicit … a twitch in a targeted muscle … recorded using electromyography (EMG) in the form of a ‘motor evoked potential’ (MEP). The amplitude, duration, and latency of MEPs are used to assess corticospinal output.”

measured_by: double-stimulation TMS with conditioning stimulus over PMd and test stimulus over M1 at specific inter-stimulus intervals
justification: “A number of studies … have found evidence for … circuits between PMd and M1, which can be reliably indexed using dsTMS methods.”
